Six Things That Have Almost Disappeared Completely From Figure Skating Figure Skating Has Changed Through the Years By Jo Ann Schneider Farris Updated August 11, 2015 . 
At one time, the sport of figure skating always included certain things that were seen at every skating rink. These things have disappeared from the sport or have almost disappeared. The disappearance of these things does prove that the sport of figure skating has changed. Figure Skaters Practiced Compulsory Figures for Hours Each Day. Michael Gushock - Getty Images Compulsory School Figures 
At one time, all figure skaters practiced compulsory school figures for hours and hours each day. Every ice skating competitor usually had to compete in a compulsory figure event. 
Compulsory figure events were eliminated from official ice skating competitions in the early 1990s. Compulsory figures are not done much anymore, but there has been a movement to bring them back. 
continue reading below our video 10 Best Basketball Players of All Time Caddies Held Up Figure Skating Scores. Screenshot by JO ANN Schneider Farris Caddies 
Way before there were computers or digital ways to show scores at figure skating competitions, there were figure skating caddies who helped post and share scores for a figure skating audience. The caddies would stand in the middle of the rink and when a whistle blew, the caddies would simultaneously hold up a figure skater's competition scores. Daniel Ryan and Carol Ann Peters - 1953 US Ice Dancing Champions and 1953 and 1952 World Ice Dancing Bronze Medalists. Photo Courtesy of Sheryl Ryan Nolan Skating Clothes Made Out of Fabric That Does Not Stretch 
There was a time when practice skating dresses and skating clothes worn at ice skating competitions were made of polyester double knit or of thick fabrics that did not stretch. Darts and gussets made these costumes fit a figure skater's body, and there was even a time where one-piece skating dresses with attached skirts did not yet exist. 
Many male figure skaters wore one-piece jumpsuits made out of thick polyester fabric. They looked like they were wearing a special suit designed for a formal party. As time went on, boys began to skate in special stretchy skating pants and shirts.
